questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Targeted biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a symptomatic patient with a visible cervical lesion and postcoital bleeding, a targeted biopsy is the appropriate next step to obtain a definitive diagnosis.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 327, DC Dutta’a Textbook of gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 327, DC Dutta’a Textbook of gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: A female presents to OPD with 6 weeks of amenorrhea complaints of bleeding per vagina and mild abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is positive and hCG level is 2800 IU/L. On investigation, mass is seen on the left adnexa measuring 3 x 2 cm. She is hemodynamically stable. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Single-dose methotrexate injection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy in a hemodynamically stable patient with an hCG level less than 5000 IU/L and an adnexal mass smaller than 3.5 cm is typically treated with a single-dose methotrexate injection.

questions.text: The most potent natural estrogen is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Estradiol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Estradiol is the most potent natural estrogen, especially during a woman’s reproductive years, due to its high receptor affinity and significant physiological effects

questions.text: Fixative for PAP smear: (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 95% ethyl alcohol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most commonly used fixative for a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol, which preserves cellular morphology necessary for accurate cytological evaluation.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 271, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 271, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman visits her obstetrician for a routine prenatal appointment at 20 weeks of gestation. Which of the following factors would not automatically categorize her current pregnancy as high-risk?

options.label: B
options.text: Previous manual removal of the placenta

questions.correct_answer: B. Previous manual removal of the placenta
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Previous manual removal of the placenta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High-risk pregnancies are defined by factors that increase the risk of complications for the mother or fetus, such as chronic health conditions, pregnancy-specific disorders, and certain lifestyle factors. Previous manual removal of the placenta does not automatically classify a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk unless associated with other complications.

questions.text: A woman at 26 weeks of gestation presents for routine evaluation. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 24 weeks. Ultrasonography revealed decreased amniotic fluid. Which of the following conditions would have led to this presentation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early onset oligohydramnios can be caused by renal anomalies, with bilateral renal agenesis being a primary condition leading to reduced amniotic fluid levels.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 670, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 670, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrectly matched? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cystocele - Colposuspension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For cystocele, the appropriate surgical management is anterior colporrhaphy, not colposuspension.

questions.text: A pregnant woman delivered a baby with the normal expulsion of an intact placenta. After half an hour she started bleeding per vaginal. On examination, she was hypotensive, and a boggy mass was palpated per abdomen. Ultrasound showed retained placental tissues. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Placenta succenturiate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Placenta succenturiata is characterized by an additional lobe of placental tissue separate from the main placenta, which can be retained postpartum, leading to hemorrhage and requiring careful monitoring and management.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for progression to borderline ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nulliparity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nulliparity is recognized as a risk factor for borderline ovarian tumors, highlighting the influence of reproductive factors on ovarian health.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of fetal biophysical profile? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Contraction stress test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Contraction Stress Test is not a component of the fetal biophysical profile.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 122, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 122, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition

questions.text: You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine US scan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspect overt diabetes? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 126 mg/dL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Overt diabetes in pregnancy is diagnosed with a fasting blood sugar level of ≥ 126 mg/dL, and maternal hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Which test is used for screening Down’s syndrome in the first trimester? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Beta HCG and PAPP-A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ First-trimester screening for Down’s syndrome primarily involves measuring Beta hCG and PAPP-A levels.

questions.text: A couple already has 3 children and has been trying for another one for the last 1 year. However, the husband is diagnosed with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Which of the following is/are true? (INICET MAY 2022) Low FSH, low LH High FSH, low LH Oligospermia Low prolactin Low testosterone
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, both FSH and LH levels are low, testosterone levels are low, and oligospermia is often present.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following would be considered as an absolute contraindication for insertion of copper T to a patient? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Unmotivated patient

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An unmotivated patient or one who does not consent is an absolute contraindication for the insertion of a copper T intrauterine device (IUD).
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 480
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 480

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding the period of gestation calculation: (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: 1st trimester USG is the best assessment

options.label: B
options.text: Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period

options.label: C
options.text: In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG

options.label: D
options.text: Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester

questions.correct_answer: B. Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gestational age is calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP), not the last day.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg, Dutta’s 108, 109, textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg127
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg, Dutta’s 108, 109, textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg127

questions.text: A 56-year-old multipara woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stress incontinence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stress urinary incontinence is characterized by involuntary leakage of urine due to increased intra-abdominal pressure and is commonly seen in women with utero-vaginal prolapse.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 597, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 597, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is recommended by the WHO for the management of the second stage of labor? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: Manual perineal support and warm compresses

options.label: C
options.text: Maintain head in deflexion and deliver

questions.correct_answer: B. Manual perineal support and warm compresses
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Manual perineal support and warm compresses

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Manual perineal support and warm compresses are recommended by the WHO to reduce perineal trauma during the second stage of labor.
  • ➤ Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below? (INICET MAY 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

questions.correct_answer: A. Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clue cells, which are epithelial cells with bacteria attached on their surface, are the most reliable microscopic indicator of bacterial vaginosis.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who has had 2 children through normal delivery presents with a dull aching pain over the abdomen, with irregular menses. Per vaginal examination revealed a mass felt through the posterior fornix. A USG showed a clear ovarian cyst of size 5 x 5 cm. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Follow up after 6 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a reproductive-aged woman with a clear ovarian cyst less than 8 cm and minimal symptoms, the best approach is to follow up with a repeat ultrasound after 6-12 weeks, rather than immediate intervention.
  • ➤ Ref: RCOG greentop guideline number 62 , Williams textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg217
  • ➤ Ref: RCOG greentop guideline number 62 , Williams textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg217

questions.text: A 24-year-old medical student is attending a lecture on contraceptive methods. During the discussion, the student asks the instructor to explain how oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) prevent pregnancy. The instructor reviews the mechanisms by which OCPs work and addresses a common misconception about their function. At the end of the lecture, the instructor asks Which of the following is NOT a mechanism of action of oral contraceptive pills?

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH)

questions.correct_answer: B. Increasing the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B. Increasing the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oral contraceptives prevent pregnancy by inhibiting ovulation, thickening cervical mucus, altering tubal motility, and maintaining a less receptive endometrium. They do not increase the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH); rather, they inhibit it, which is central to their effectiveness in preventing conception.

questions.text: All the followings are seen in Gestational Diabetes Mellitus except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Malformations

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital anomalies are not typically seen with Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM); they are associated with pre-existing overt diabetes mellitus.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg 2787
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg 2787

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test came with complaints of lower abdominal pain, moderate bleeding PV. She was hemodynamically stable. On ultrasound, there was no gestational sac in the uterus. Ovaries were normal and no free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Follow-up with beta-HCG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, a positive pregnancy test, and no gestational sac visible on ultrasound, the next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels to differentiate between an early intrauterine pregnancy, an ectopic pregnancy, and a miscarriage.
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg 356
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg 356

questions.text: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sheehan’s syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sheehan’s syndrome is characterized by postpartum hemorrhage leading to vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels, resulting in panhypopituitarism with symptoms like lactation failure and amenorrhea.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 458, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 458, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: A patient with an adnexal mass underwent surgery, and the following tumor was removed. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Mature teratoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mature teratomas, or dermoid cysts, are characterized by the presence of differentiated tissues such as hair, teeth, and sebaceous material, making them identifiable upon gross examination

questions.text: A patient has just delivered a full-term baby and developed uterine inversion with the placenta still attached. What is the immediate next step? (INICET NOV 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Remove placenta and reposition the uterus

options.label: B
options.text: Put uterus inside without removing the placenta

options.label: C
options.text: Shift to OT and insert the uterus back

questions.correct_answer: B. Put uterus inside without removing the placenta
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Put uterus inside without removing the placenta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the case of uterine inversion, the uterus should be repositioned with the placenta still attached to avoid significant bleeding, followed by medical management for uterine contraction.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lichen Sclerosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational
  • ➤ Objective
  • ➤ When encountering white atrophic papules and plaques on the vulva that may coalesce and distort the vulvar anatomy, lichen sclerosus should be considered as a primary diagnosis.

questions.text: Type I collagen is not seen in? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Elastic cartilage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ List of types of collagens in various tissues:
  • ➤ List of types of collagens in various tissues:

questions.text: What is vagitus uterinus? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Cry of baby in the womb

options.label: D
options.text: Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.correct_answer: A. Cry of baby in the womb
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cry of baby in the womb

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vagitus uterinus refers to the cry of a baby in the womb, which is a rare phenomenon that can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry.

questions.text: A patient has Bilateral right sided loss of vision. What is the most likely site of lesion. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Understanding the visual pathway is critical for localizing lesions based on patterns of visual field loss. Lesions at different points along the visual pathway (e.g., optic nerves, chiasma, tracts, or radiations) will produce characteristic visual field defects. This knowledge is used to guide further diagnostic testing and management, which may include imaging studies like MRI or CT scans to visualize the lesion and determine its cause.

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulant requires coagulation profile monitoring? ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Lepirudin

questions.text: Dofetilide belongs to which class of anti-arrhythmic drugs? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Class III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Class III drugs include:
  • ➤ Class III drugs include:
  • ➤ B: Bretylium
  • ➤ I: Ibutilide
  • ➤ N
  • ➤ D: Dofetilide
  • ➤ A: Amiodarone
  • ➤ S: Sotalol

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of asthma and sinusitis. On looking into his medical records, you notice this has been attributed to Samter's triad. Which drug should be avoided in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aspirin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients diagnosed with Samter's triad, it is crucial to avoid aspirin and other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1, as these can trigger severe respiratory and nasal symptoms. Effective management involves identifying safe medications for pain and inflammation and regularly monitoring the respiratory and nasal health of the patient.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 193, 194
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 193, 194

questions.text: A 18-year-old girl presents to the clinic with concerns of primary amenorrhea and lack of breast development. On physical examination, she is noted to have Prader 3 genitalia, indicating significant virilization with an increased phallic size and partial labioscrotal fusion. Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated levels of Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH). Further imaging with pelvic ultrasound reveals Mullerian structures, but the gonads are poorly visualized. A karyotype analysis shows 45, XO/46, XY mosaicism. Given these findings, what would be the next best step in management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Hormone replacement therapy with estrogen and progesterone

options.label: D
options.text: Regular monitoring of gonads with ultrasound

questions.explanation:
Ans.  B. Bilateral gonadectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with gonadal dysgenesis and a Y chromosome, such as those with 45,X0/46,XY mosaicism, bilateral gonadectomy is crucial to eliminate the significant risk of malignancy. Prophylactic removal of dysgenetic gonads is prioritized to prevent cancer, followed by hormone replacement therapy to manage pubertal development and long-term health.

questions.text: Identify the type of hypoxia according to given graph: (Brown graph is normal) ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anemic hypoxia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stagnant hypoxia: Oxygen deficiency due to poor blood circulation. Histotoxic hypoxia: Cells unable to utilize oxygen despite its availability. Hypoxic hypoxia: Generalized lack of oxygen in the body's tissues. Anemic hypoxia: Reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood due to low hemoglobin.
  • ➤ Stagnant hypoxia: Oxygen deficiency due to poor blood circulation.
  • ➤ Histotoxic hypoxia: Cells unable to utilize oxygen despite its availability.
  • ➤ Hypoxic hypoxia: Generalized lack of oxygen in the body's tissues.
  • ➤ Anemic hypoxia: Reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood due to low hemoglobin.

questions.text: Which among the following is an ideal treatment for a 55-year-old female with simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Simple hysterectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia, the ideal treatment is a total hysterectomy to prevent progression to endometrial carcinoma.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 330, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 330, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamezapine than oxcarbazepine , except ? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hyponatremia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While both carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause similar side effects, hyponatremia is notably more prevalent with oxcarbazepine.

questions.text: Modified Robson's classification class 1 includes: (INICET MAY 2020)

options.label: C
options.text: Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour

options.label: D
options.text: Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour

questions.correct_answer: B. Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Class 1 of the Modified Robson's classification includes nulliparous women with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and are in spontaneous labor.
  • ➤ Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/259512/9789241513197-eng.pdf?sequence=1
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/259512/9789241513197-eng.pdf?sequence=1

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with progressive blurred vision, photophobia, and eye pain. On examination, there was conjunctival redness, a mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye. He has been treated both medically and surgically for the condition but showed no improvement. The following procedure incorporates a device to aid drainage. Identify the device. (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ex-Press™ implant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant is a minimally invasive device used during modified trabeculectomy to enhance aqueous drainage and reduce intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma. This implant is characterized by its stainless-steel construction and effectiveness in controlling glaucoma with fewer hypotony-related complications.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to a fertility clinic with his spouse after 12 months of unprotected intercourse without any conception. He denies any history of erectile dysfunction or sexually transmitted infections. His medical history is unremarkable, and he has not undergone any surgeries. A semen analysis reveals azoospermia. A scrotal ultrasound shows the absence of bilateral vas deferens. The patient has no history of lung disease or gastrointestinal symptoms. The congenital absence of seminal vesicles and vas deferens is most commonly associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Cystic fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis is associated with congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens (CBAVD) , a condition that leads to obstructive azoospermia and infertility in males. CBAVD may occur as an isolated feature of cystic fibrosis without the classical pulmonary or gastrointestinal manifestations of the disease.
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis
  • ➤ congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens (CBAVD)

questions.text: Identify the disorder with X-linked dominant inheritance: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rett syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant disorder most commonly seen in girls, characterized by microcephaly, regression of motor milestones, developmental delay, and stereotyped movements.

questions.text: A patient on anti-tubercular therapy develops tingling sensation in the limbs. Which of the following when substituted can result from in improvement of symptoms? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pyridoxine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation is essential for patients receiving isoniazid as part of their anti-tubercular therapy to prevent or manage peripheral neuropathy symptoms.

questions.text: Match the following Interleukins with their effector cells? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child is presented with multiple times loose stools. He is managed with ORS. Glucose in ORS is absorbed via which transporter in GIT?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) SGLT-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ SGLT-1 is the key transporter responsible for the absorption of glucose in the gastrointestinal tract. This mechanism is crucial in the management of conditions like diarrhea, where ORS containing glucose can help rehydrate the body by enhancing fluid absorption.
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 538
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ -Harper 31 st e/pg. 538

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient arrives at the emergency department with a history of stabbing injury to her arm. Upon examination, there is a noticeable hematoma, and the patient reports not feeling any radial or ulnar pulses in the affected arm. Imaging reveals a 3cm longitudinal tear in the brachial artery. The medical team is faced with deciding the best treatment option for the patient. Which option should they choose? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: Repair with great saphenous vein graft

questions.correct_answer: B. Repair with great saphenous vein graft
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Repair with great saphenous vein graft

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Repair with a great saphenous vein graft is an appropriate choice in cases of brachial artery injury with extensive damage and vascular compromise, allowing for the restoration of blood flow to the arm. This surgical intervention should be performed urgently to prevent further ischemic complications in the affected limb.

questions.text: A HIV patient with fever, chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool? (INICET MAY 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin

options.label: B
options.text: Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue

options.label: C
options.text: Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet

options.label: D
options.text: Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin

questions.correct_answer: B. Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain uses methanol for fixation, Kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin as the primary stain, acid alcohol for decolorization, and methylene blue as the counterstain to detect acid-fast organisms like Cryptosporidium parvum.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with amenorrhea. On examination, she had normal genitalia & normal breast development. Her tests reveal a 5 alpha-reductase deficiency. What could be the probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Male pseudohermaphrodite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Male pseudohermaphroditism involves male gonads with female external genitalia. In 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, there is a failure of the testis to descend and ill development of the penis, resulting in a female phenotype despite having male internal genitalia.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 443
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 443

questions.text: All of the following supply the structure marked ‘E’ except? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Diagonal artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the vascular supply of the heart is crucial, especially in clinical settings dealing with coronary artery disease. The right ventricle is primarily supplied by the right coronary artery and its branches, including the marginal artery. The diagonal artery, a branch of the left coronary system (specifically the anterior interventricular artery), mainly supplies the left ventricle and does not contribute significantly to the blood supply of the right ventricle.

questions.text: A man in his 50s comes to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. During the examination, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is measured at 90/50mmg. Guarding is observed during a per abdomen examination. An erect abdominal X-ray is provided. What is the best management in this case based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Exploratory laparotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air or gas within the peritoneal cavity, the space within the abdomen that contains the intestines, liver, and other abdominal organs.
  • ➤ Pneumoperitoneum
  • ➤ Clinical Presentation and Diagnosis:
  • ➤ Clinical Presentation and Diagnosis:
  • ➤ Patients with a significant amount of free air in the peritoneal cavity due to organ perforation often present with severe abdominal pain, signs of peritonitis (like guarding and rebound tenderness), and systemic symptoms like fever or shock. An erect abdominal X-ray is a commonly used diagnostic modality to detect pneumoperitoneum. On the X-ray, free air under the diaphragm, or "free subdiaphragmatic air", is a classic finding.

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bilateral hydrosalpinx

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydrosalpinx is characterized by bilaterally enlarged Fallopian tubes filled with clear fluid, often due to repeated mild infections causing obstruction and distension.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 171, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 171, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: A new diagnostic test for dengue is being evaluated using a Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) graph. As the curve transitions from the green region to the pink region, what is the most likely change in the test characteristics? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.correct_answer: A. Both sensitivity and specificity increase
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Both sensitivity and specificity increase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ On an ROC graph, a transition from one region to another indicating improved test performance generally means that both sensitivity and specificity are increasing.
  • ➤ On an ROC graph, a transition from one region to another indicating improved test performance generally means that both sensitivity and specificity are increasing.

questions.text: A child presents with erythematous scaly patches in the perioral region, mucosal ulcers, and impaired epithelial wound healing. What is the likely mineral deficiency associated with this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Zinc deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zinc deficiency disorder- Acrodermatitis enteropathica
  • ➤ Zinc deficiency disorder- Acrodermatitis enteropathica

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with an abnormal Pap smear that revealed carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix, confirmed by colposcopy and biopsy. She has no visible macroscopic growth on examination, and her past medical history is unremarkable. She expresses concern about her fertility as she has not yet started a family. The gynecologist discusses the appropriate management options considering her age, fertility desires, and the stage of her disease. What is the recommended next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Conization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carcinoma in situ (Stage 0 cervical cancer) involves the full thickness of the cervical epithelium without basement membrane invasion. The preferred management in young women desiring fertility is conization, which serves both diagnostic and curative roles. More invasive procedures like radical hysterectomy or chemoradiation are reserved for more advanced disease stages.

questions.text: Calculate the Downe score of a newborn who has cyanosis which improves on giving oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, air entry markedly decreased, RR 40 per minute? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. A score of 6 in this case indicates moderate respiratory distress, characterized by cyanosis that improves with oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, markedly decreased air entry, and a normal respiratory rate.

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the colon are caused by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Entameoba histolytica

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Entamoeba histolytica is the cause of flask-shaped ulcers in the colon, distinguishing it from other intestinal pathogens due to its invasive capabilities and the characteristic morphology of the ulcers it creates. Understanding these features helps in the differential diagnosis of dysentery and guides appropriate treatment and management strategies.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning is? ( INICET May 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Dimercaprol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment of Acute Arsenic poisoning
  • ➤ Treatment of Acute Arsenic poisoning
  • ➤ Hemodynamic stabilization for significant GI losses (vomiting and diarrhea) Gastric lavage is done repeatedly with large amount of warm water and milk; Chelating Agents Chelating agents are useful in acute arsenic poisoning, but have very limited role in chronic arsenic poisoning There are three chelating agents useful in acute arsenic poisoning: British Anti Lewisite (BAL, aka dimercaprol, dimercaptopropanol): available in IM route. Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.
  • ➤ Hemodynamic stabilization for significant GI losses (vomiting and diarrhea)
  • ➤ Gastric lavage is done repeatedly with large amount of warm water and milk;
  • ➤ Chelating Agents Chelating agents are useful in acute arsenic poisoning, but have very limited role in chronic arsenic poisoning There are three chelating agents useful in acute arsenic poisoning: British Anti Lewisite (BAL, aka dimercaprol, dimercaptopropanol): available in IM route. Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.
  • ➤ Chelating Agents
  • ➤ Chelating agents are useful in acute arsenic poisoning, but have very limited role in chronic arsenic poisoning There are three chelating agents useful in acute arsenic poisoning: British Anti Lewisite (BAL, aka dimercaprol, dimercaptopropanol): available in IM route. Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.
  • ➤ Chelating agents are useful in acute arsenic poisoning, but have very limited role in chronic arsenic poisoning
  • ➤ There are three chelating agents useful in acute arsenic poisoning: British Anti Lewisite (BAL, aka dimercaprol, dimercaptopropanol): available in IM route. Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.
  • ➤ British Anti Lewisite (BAL, aka dimercaprol, dimercaptopropanol): available in IM route. Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.

  • ➤ British Anti Lewisite
  • ➤ Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman who had an abdominal hysterectomy two years ago and is now experiencing abdominal pain, vomiting bile, high-pitched bowel sounds during examination. The presence of air within the biliary tree is seen on diagnostic tests. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gallstone ileus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis characterized by the presence of air within the biliary tree, obstructive symptoms, and the formation of a cholecysto-duodenal fistula. It typically presents with signs of gastrointestinal obstruction and is diagnosed through imaging, revealing pneumobilia and a gallstone in the intestines.
  • ➤ Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis characterized by the presence of air within the biliary tree, obstructive symptoms, and the formation of a cholecysto-duodenal fistula.
  • ➤ It typically presents with signs of gastrointestinal obstruction and is diagnosed through imaging, revealing pneumobilia and a gallstone in the intestines.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient has grade III ASA. Which of the following post bronchodilator PFT findings requires further evaluation of the lung function of the patient? ( INICET Nov 2021) ASA- American Society of Anesthesiology PFT- Pulmonary function test FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in 1 second FVC- Forced vital capacity
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of lung function.
  • ➤ GOLD criteria for COPD is given as follows:
  • ➤ GOLD criteria for COPD is given as follows:
  • ➤ Abbreviations : COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; GOLD, Global Initiative for Lung Disease
  • ➤ Abbreviations
  • ➤ As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of the lung function.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 950
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg
  • ➤ 950

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency room with active variceal bleeding. Which of the following interventions is not typically performed in this situation? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Platelet transfusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Management of variceal bleeding:
  • ➤ Initial resuscitation: The first step in the management of variceal bleeding is to stabilize the patient with aggressive resuscitation measures, including airway management, fluid and blood product resuscitation, and correction of coagulopathy. Endoscopy: Early endoscopy allows for the identification of the bleeding site and the application of endoscopic therapies such as band ligation or sclerotherapy. Pharmacological therapy: Vasopressin and its analogs (such as terlipressin) are commonly used in the management of variceal bleeding to decrease portal pressure and reduce the risk of re-bleeding. Antibiotics: Prophylactic antibiotics are recommended in patients with variceal bleeding to reduce the risk of bacterial infections, such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS): In patients with recurrent bleeding despite endoscopic and pharmacological therapy, TIPS may be considered to reduce portal pressure and prevent further bleeding. Surgery: In rare cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to control variceal bleeding, particularly in patients with refractory bleeding or severe liver disease.
  • ➤ Initial resuscitation: The first step in the management of variceal bleeding is to stabilize the patient with aggressive resuscitation measures, including airway management, fluid and blood product resuscitation, and correction of coagulopathy.
  • ➤ Endoscopy: Early endoscopy allows for the identification of the bleeding site and the application of endoscopic therapies such as band ligation or sclerotherapy.
  • ➤ Pharmacological therapy: Vasopressin and its analogs (such as terlipressin) are commonly used in the management of variceal bleeding to decrease portal pressure and reduce the risk of re-bleeding.
  • ➤ Antibiotics: Prophylactic antibiotics are recommended in patients with variceal bleeding to reduce the risk of bacterial infections, such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
  • ➤ Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS): In patients with recurrent bleeding despite endoscopic and pharmacological therapy, TIPS may be considered to reduce portal pressure and prevent further bleeding.
  • ➤ Surgery: In rare cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to control variceal bleeding, particularly in patients with refractory bleeding or severe liver disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prokinetic? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Diphenylmethane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diphenylmethane is not a prokinetic drug and is not used to treat gastrointestinal motility disorders. Prokinetic drugs include 5HT4 agonists, dopamine antagonists, and macrolides, which all act to enhance gastrointestinal motility.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of inability to move his 4th and 5th digit, cannot hold a pen and he was not able to hold a paper between fingers. Which of the following sites given below is the probable cause of injury to the nerve in question? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 7

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tests for ulnar nerve lesions are as follows:
  • ➤ Tests for ulnar nerve lesions are as follows:
  • ➤ 1. Card Test : This isn't a widely recognized test in the context of ulnar nerve pathology. However, in some practices, the card test might refer to asking the patient to hold a card (like a credit card) between their thumb and the side of their index finger. Difficulty or inability to do this due to a weak adductor pollicis muscle (innervated by the ulnar nerve) may suggest ulnar nerve dysfunction.
  • ➤ 1. Card Test
  • ➤ 2. Claw Hand Deformity : This is seen in ulnar nerve injuries. In a typical ulnar claw hand, the 4th and 5th digits (ring and little fingers) are hyperextended at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexed at the interphalangeal (IP) joints. This occurs due to the loss of function of the lumbricals and interossei of the hand, which are innervated by the ulnar nerve.
  • ➤ 2. Claw Hand Deformity
  • ➤ 3. Froment's Sign : This is a classic sign of ulnar nerve palsy. The patient is asked to hold a piece of paper between their thumb and the side of their index finger (pinch grip). If the ulnar nerve is compromised, the patient will compensate by flexing the thumb's IP joint to maintain grip strength, which is a positive Froment's sign. This indicates weakness or paralysis of the adductor pollicis muscle.
  • ➤ 3. Froment's Sign
  • ➤ 4. Wartenberg Sign : In ulnar nerve injury, there's unopposed action of the extensor digiti minimi, which leads to abduction of the little finger. The patient will be unable to bring their little finger back to the side of the hand, leading to the "Wartenberg sign."
  • ➤ 4. Wartenberg Sign
  • ➤ 5. Palmaris Brevis Sign : This is a sign of ulnar nerve functionality. The palmaris brevis muscle is innervated by the ulnar nerve. Upon tapping or massaging the hypothenar eminence (palm side of the hand, base of the little finger), contraction of the palmaris brevis muscle can be observed as a twitching or dimpling. If present, it indicates that at least part of the ulnar nerve's function remains intact.
  • ➤ 5. Palmaris Brevis Sign
